ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course? (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I learned how to think critically about texts, how to put them in conversation with each other, refine my points, and write more effectively.
I learned how to better close read and deeply analyze the text of literature.
I honed my close reading and critical essay writing skills.
I greatly improved my writing skills and my appreciation for the function of literature.

The breadth of literature covered in Directed Studies is hugely rewarding to learn about, whether from readings, discussions with my peers, or in-depth analysis through papers. In particular, my ability to close read and write an analytical paper has improved greatly over the course of this semester.
Written analysis, verbal reasoning, rigorous discussion, broader insights regarding the Western canon

I developed my ability to identify common themes across texts and analyze them, I practiced my writing in regards to style and clarity.  Writing reading responses for each class was very helpful in developing ideas.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved? (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Strengths are that you cover a wide range of texts, yet it can be difficult to cover many important things within them because of lack of time.
GREAT
I enjoyed our tight-knit seminar. Professor Hagens always encouraged us to share our analyses of the text and build off of each others' responses.

I really enjoyed my section as a classit was always the highlight of my week, but I think that was more a function of my professor and my classmates. The syllabus was very interesting at first, but towards the end, it felt like my engagement with the texts was lacking. I truly enjoyed listening to the importance of Omeros and its sections on postcolonial reckonings, but I had a lot of difficulty actually reading the text.

One of the strengths of this course is the requirement that we write a reading response before every class. I really enjoyed how this structured our class time and allowed everyone to participate and share their insights, and also how it aided in studying for finals and generating essay topics!
STRENGTHS: welcoming and rigorous discussion environment created by Professor Hagens; willingness of instructor to meet students outside of class

This course was great and Prof. Hagens is fantastic.  Our discussions were very rigorous and benefitted from the incorporation of our reading responses into the seminar.  I feel like this course offers a lot not only in terms of the work on the syllabus, but in terms of analytical skills in general.  Prof. Hagens provided clear feedback on every reading response, essay, and on our participation in class.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Writing on the discussion boards before class was actually very helpful in guiding discussion.
more social
I appreciated how accessible Professor Hagens' Zoom office hours were.

Our section had Zoom breakout sessions for 5-10 minutes in the middle of each seminar to serve both as a break to combat Zoom fatigue and a way to get to know our classmates better and build the sorely lacking sense of community. These were incredibly helpful and even helped improve overall focus and engagement with the class.
Virtual office hours were a fantastic opportunity.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I would definitely recommend this course. I'm leaving Professor Hagen's class not only with a greatly enhanced body of work I'm now familiar with, but also with an ability to discuss texts on a higher level.
YES
Yes! I truly enjoyed all of the works on the syllabus and was always excited to learn about them together through discussions with my classmates and Professor Hagens in seminar.

I really enjoyed the opportunity to read such great works of literature and to discuss them with a fantastic professor and wonderful classmates. Some of the lectures, especially those of Professor Soles, were also incredible.
I would absolutely recommend Directed Studies to anyone looking to have a more structured first year of classes, as well as a close knit community of classmates!

Yes; welcoming environment of seminar increases student participation and makes for a lively discussion space.  Solid written feedback allows for improvement in papers throughout the course of the semester.

I would recommend this course to another student if they are interested in developing their ability to interact with literature.  I had not read most of the authors in the ds syllabus prior to the program, and I felt like it was accessible, especially given the amount and clarity of Prof. Hagens' feedback.

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: There were pre-recorded lectures as well.
with recorded lecture
We had weekly seminars, discussion posts, papers, readings, and lectures.
N/A
Virtual office hours; Canvas discussion threads
